problem.markdown:
>>1. Which monolithic repository did the Open edX project originally start with?<< (!) frontend-app-learning (x) edx-platform ( ) tutor ( ) frontend-app-discussions
>>2. What is the main function of XBlocks in the Open edX platform?<< (!) To encapsulate frontend functionality ( ) To provide a visually consistent user experience (x) To be modular building blocks that o power courseware that students interact with ( ) To manage repositories
>>3. Which MFE is a student interacting with when they are viewing courseware pages?<< (x) frontend-app-learning (!) frontend-app-discussions ( ) frontend-app-gradebook ( ) frontend-app-studio
>>4. What is Paragon in the Open edX project?<< (!) A tutorial system ( ) A backend API (x) An accessible, theme-ready design system with reusable components ( ) A repository for course certificates
>>5. Which of the following are features provided by Paragon in the Open edX project?<< [x] Provides components such as Buttons and Dropdowns [!] Comes with a postgres database [x] Supports Internationalization and accessibility [x] Ensures consistency across MFEs [ ] Includes a data analytics tool
>>6. Which of the following steps are involved in debugging with Tutor in the Open edX project?<< [x] Add a breakpoint in the Django view using breakpoint() [x] Attach a terminal to the standard output of an LMS service [!] Use SQL to debug library errors [x] Trigger the view and check the output in the command line [ ] Run "npm install" commands to manage errors
>>7. Why is version control necessary for Open edX source code development?<< (!) To reduce the number of repositories ( ) To handle high-volume traffic (x) To create a clear, readable history of changes mades ( ) To make sure developers never have to talk to each other
>>8. What does forking a repository on GitHub enable you to do?<< (x) Create a personal copy of a repo for modifications and contributions (!) Delete repositories on the main project ( ) Directly merge changes into the upstream repo ( ) Avoid using pull requests
>>9. What does the command "git remote add upstream https://github.com/orgname/reponame" do?<< (!) Deletes a remote repository ( ) Clones the repository (x) Adds a new remote repository to your local repository ( ) Updates the local repository with the latest upstream commits
>>10. What is the main goal of rebasing in Git?<< (!) Directly merge forks to the main branch (x) Replay a branch’s commits on top of the latest commits from the main branch ( ) Remove the history of a branch ( ) Create a clone of an upstream repository
>>11. Which commands are used to update your local branch with the latest changes from the upstream master branch?<< [x] git fetch upstream [x] git merge upstream/master [!] git push origin main [ ] git clone [x] git checkout master
>>12. What steps should be followed to create and switch to a new branch in Git?<< [x] Use "git branch branch-name" to create a branch [x] Use "git checkout branch-name" to switch to the branch [x] Use "git checkout -b branch-name" to create and switch at the same time [!] Use "git merge branch-name" to delete a branch [ ] Use "git remove branchname" to rebase the branch
>>13. What command is commonly used to run backend tests in Open edX repositories?<< (!) npm run test (x) make test ( ) pytest start ( ) dev logs lms -f
>>14. Which of the following practices is preferred in the Open edX coding standards?<< (!) Short variable names like `ck` ( ) Ignoring comments in the code (x) Verbose, easy-to-understand variable names ( ) Complicated nested list comprehensions
>>15. What documentation system does Open edX follow?<< (x) Diátaxis (!) ISO 9001 ( ) Agile documentation framework ( ) PRINCE2
>>16. To which accessibility standard does Open edX strive to comply?<< (x) WCAG 2.2 (!) ISO 14001 ( ) OHSAS 18001 ( ) IEEE 802.11
>>17. Which practices contribute to high code quality in the Open edX community?<< [x] Writing verbose and easy-to-understand code [x] Using linters like pylint and ESLint [!] Avoiding docstrings and comments [x] Following conventional commit guidelines [ ] Merging branches without reviews
>>18. What is one core benefit of using MFEs (Micro Frontends) in Open edX?<< (!) Reduced number of backend APIs (x) Smaller, more maintainable codebases ( ) Faster code deployment time {{This is incorrect! Please try again.}} ( ) Server-side rendering only
>>19. How do MFEs interact with edx-platform?<< (!) By directly modifying its database ( ) Through static configurations (x) Using API calls ( ) Using SSH connections
>>20. Which advantages does Paragon have? Click all that apply. << [x] Provides consistency for your Paragon components [!] Paragon includes built-in support for cryptocurrency transactions. [x] Provides scalability for your Paragon components [ ] All its components are static [ ] Paragon is backed by a postgres database [ ] Paragon integrates directly with machine learning algorithms to optimize performance. [x] Internationalization support is provided for your Paragon components [ ] lacks accessibility support for its components.
problem.label: 1. Which monolithic repository did the Open edX project originally start with?
2. What is the main function of XBlocks in the Open edX platform?

choicegroup.choice: To provide a visually consistent user experience
To be modular building blocks that power courseware that students interact with

problem.label: 3. Which MFE is a student interacting with when they are viewing courseware pages?
4. What is Paragon in the Open edX project?

choicegroup.choice: An accessible, theme-ready design system with reusable components

problem.label: 5. Which of the following are features provided by Paragon in the Open edX project? (Select 3)

checkboxgroup.choice: Provides components such as Buttons and Dropdowns
Comes with a postgres database
Supports Internationalization and accessibility
Ensures consistency across MFEs
Includes a data analytics tool

problem.label: 6. Which of the following steps are involved in debugging with Tutor in the Open edX project? (Select 3)

checkboxgroup.choice: Add a breakpoint in the Django view using breakpoint()
Attach a terminal to the standard output of an LMS service
Use SQL to debug library errors
Trigger the view and check the output in the command line
Run "npm install" commands to manage errors

problem.label: 7. Why is version control necessary for Open edX source code development?

choicegroup.choice: To reduce the number of repositories
To create a clear, readable history of changes mades
To make sure developers never have to talk to each other

problem.label: 8. What does forking a repository on GitHub enable you to do?

choicegroup.choice: Create a personal copy of a repo for modifications and contributions
Delete repositories on the main project
Directly merge changes into the upstream repo

problem.label: 9. What does the command "git remote add upstream https://github.com/orgname/reponame" do?

choicegroup.choice: Adds a new remote repository to your local repository
Updates the local repository with the latest upstream commits

problem.label: 10. What is the main goal of rebasing in Git?

choicegroup.choice: Directly merge forks to the main branch
Replay a branch’s commits on top of the latest commits from the main branch
Remove the history of a branch
Create a clone of an upstream repository

problem.label: 11. Which commands are used to update your local branch with the latest changes from the upstream master branch? (Select 3)

checkboxgroup.choice: git fetch upstream
git merge upstream/master
git push origin main
git clone
git checkout master

problem.label: 12. What steps should be followed to create and switch to a new branch in Git? (Select 3)

checkboxgroup.choice: Use "git branch branch-name" to create a branch
Use "git checkout branch-name" to switch to the branch
Use "git checkout -b branch-name" to create and switch at the same time
Use "git merge branch-name" to delete a branch
Use "git remove branchname" to rebase the branch

problem.label: 13. What command is commonly used to run backend tests in Open edX repositories?
14. Which of the following practices is preferred in the Open edX coding standards?
15. What documentation system does Open edX follow?
16. To which accessibility standard does Open edX strive to comply?
17. Which practices contribute to high code quality in the Open edX community? (Select 3)

checkboxgroup.choice: Writing verbose and easy-to-understand code
Using linters like pylint and ESLint
Avoiding docstrings and comments
Following conventional commit guidelines
Merging branches without reviews

problem.label: 18. What is one core benefit of using MFEs (Micro Frontends) in Open edX?

choicegroup.choice: Faster code deployment time This is incorrect! Please try again.

problem.label: 19. How do MFEs interact with edx-platform?
20. Which advantages does Paragon have? (Select 3)

checkboxgroup.choice: Provides consistency for your Paragon components
Paragon includes built-in support for cryptocurrency transactions.
Provides scalability for your Paragon components
All its components are static
Paragon is backed by a postgres database
Paragon integrates directly with machine learning algorithms to optimize performance.
Internationalization support is provided for your Paragon components
Lacks accessibility support for its components.
